African Studies Association., 1975.</ref> Living at the time of King [[Shalmaneser III]] of [[Assyria]] (ruled [[859 BC|859]]–824 BC), Arame united the [[Nairi]] tribe against the threat of the [[Assyrian Empire]]. His capital at [[Arzashkun]] was captured by Shalmaneser.<ref>The Ancient Assyrians - Page 12 by Mark Healy</ref> Arame has been suggested as the prototype of both [[Aram (given name)|Aram]] (and, correspondingly the popular given name [[Aram (given name)|Aram]]<ref>"Արամ" in H. Ačaṙean (1926-35), ''Hayocʿ Anjnanunneri Baṙaran'' (Yerevan: Yerevan State University), 2nd ed., 1942-62</ref>) and [[Ara the Beautiful]], two of the legendary forefathers of the [[Armenians|Armenian]] people.<ref>Lang (1970), p. 85.</ref> Khorenatsi's ''[[History of Armenia (Moses of Chorene)|History]]'' (1.5) puts them six and seven generations after [[Hayk|Haik]], in the chronology of historian [[Mikayel Chamchian]] dated to the 19th to 18th century BC. ==See also== {{Portal|Ancient Near East}} * [[List of kings of Urartu]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *[[David Marshall Lang]], ''Armenia: Cradle of Civilization'' (1970). {{Persondata | NAME = Arame | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arame}} [[Category:Urartian kings]] [[Category:History of Armenia]] [[Category:Anatolia]] [[Category:9th-century BC rulers]] {{Armenia-royal-stub}} {{ANE-bio-stub}}
